current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend title 5, United States Code, to improve the security of the United States border and to
			 provide for reforms and rates of pay for border patrol agents.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

action-desc.#text:
Reported, under authority of the order of the Senate of August 5 (legislative day, August 1), 2014, 
			 by

action-instruction.#text: Strike out all after the enacting clause and insert the part printed in italic

short-title.#text: Border Patrol Agent Pay Reform Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
The purposes of this Act are—

to strengthen U.S. Customs and Border Protection and ensure border patrol agents are sufficiently
			 ready to conduct necessary work and that agents will perform overtime
			 hours in excess of a 40-hour work week based on the needs of the employing
			 agency; and

to ensure U.S. Customs and Border Protection has the flexibility to cover shift changes and retains
			 the right to assign scheduled and unscheduled work for mission
			 requirements and planning based on operational need.
Subchapter V of

external-xref.#tail:
of title 5, United States Code, is amended by inserting after section
			 5549 the following:

text.#text: In this section—
the term
the term

term.#tail: means a border patrol agent is—

text.#text: the term

detecting and preventing illegal entry and smuggling of aliens, commercial goods, narcotics,
			 weapons, or contraband into the United States;
arresting individuals suspected of conduct described in subparagraph (A);
attending training authorized by U.S. Customs and Border Protection;
on approved annual, sick, or administrative leave;
on ordered travel status;
on official time, within the meaning of section 7131;
on excused absence with pay for relocation purposes;
on light duty due to injury or disability;

performing administrative duties or mission critical work assignments while maintaining law
			 enforcement authority;
caring for the canine assigned to the border patrol agent, which may not exceed 1 hour per day; or

term.#tail:
means the hourly rate of pay equal to 1.25 times the otherwise applicable hourly rate of basic pay
			 of the applicable border patrol agent;
term.#text: level 1 border patrol rate of pay

text.#text: the term

term.#tail:
means the hourly rate of pay equal to 1.125 times the otherwise applicable hourly rate of basic
			 pay of the applicable border patrol agent; and
term.#text: level 2 border patrol rate of pay

text.#text: the term
the term

header.#text: Receipt of border patrol rate of pay

text.#text: be assigned to the level 1 border patrol rate of pay;
be assigned the level 2 border patrol rate of pay; or

decline to be assigned the level 1 border patrol rate of pay or the level 2 border patrol rate of
			 pay.

Not later than 30 days before the first day of each year beginning after the date of enactment of
			 this section, a border patrol agent shall make an election whether the
			 border patrol agent shall, for the following year—

The Director of the Office of Personnel Management shall establish procedures for elections under
			 subparagraph (A).

Not later than 60 days before the first day of each year beginning after the date of enactment of
			 this section, U.S. Customs and Border Protection shall provide each border
			 patrol agent with information regarding each type of election available
			 under subparagraph (A) and how to make such an election.

A border patrol agent who fails to make a timely election under subparagraph (A) shall be deemed to
			 have made an election to be assigned to the level 1 border patrol rate of
			 pay under subparagraph (A)(i).

It is the sense of Congress that U.S. Customs and Border Protection should take such action as is
			 necessary to ensure that not more than 10 percent of the border patrol
			 agents stationed at a location decline to be assigned to the level 1
			 border patrol rate of pay or the level 2 border patrol rate of pay.

header.#text: Level 1 border patrol rate of pay

text.#text: For a border patrol agent who has in effect an election under paragraph (1)(A)(i)—
the border patrol agent shall be scheduled to work, for 5 days per week—
8 hours of regular time per day; and

2 additional hours of scheduled overtime during each day the border patrol agent is scheduled to
			 work under clause (i);

for the hours of regular time work described in subparagraph (A)(i), the border patrol agent shall
			 receive pay at the level 1 border patrol rate of pay;

for the hours of regularly scheduled overtime work described in subparagraph (A)(ii), the border
			 patrol agent shall not receive—
additional compensation under this section or any other provision of law; or
compensatory time off;

shall receive compensatory time off or pay at the overtime hourly rate of pay for hours of work in
			 excess of 100 hours during a work period, as determined in accordance with
			 section 5542(a)(7); and

shall be charged leave in increments of 8 hours for 1 shift of leave, regardless of the length of
			 the shift.

header.#text: Level 2 border patrol rate of pay

text.#text: For a border patrol agent who has in effect an election under paragraph (1)(A)(ii)—
the border patrol agent shall be scheduled to work, for 5 days per week—
8 hours of regular time per day; and

1 additional hour of scheduled overtime during each day the border patrol agent is scheduled to
			 work under clause (i);

for the hours of regular time work described in subparagraph (A)(i), the border patrol agent shall
			 receive pay at the level 2 border patrol rate of pay;

for the hours of regularly scheduled overtime work described in subparagraph (A)(ii), the border
			 patrol agent shall not receive—
additional compensation under this section or any other provision of law; or
compensatory time off;

shall receive compensatory time off or pay at the overtime hourly rate of pay for hours of work in
			 excess of 90 hours during a work period, as determined in accordance with
			 section 5542(a)(7); and

shall be charged leave in increments of 8 hours for 1 shift of leave, regardless of the length of
			 the shift.

header.#text: Basic border patrol rate of pay

text.#text: For a border patrol agent who has in effect an election under paragraph (1)(A)(iii)—

the border patrol agent shall be scheduled to work 8 hours of regular time per day and 5 days per
			 week;

the border patrol agent shall receive compensatory time off or pay at the overtime hourly rate of
			 pay for hours of work in excess of 80 hours during a work period, as
			 determined in accordance with section 5542(a)(7).
A border patrol agent—

shall receive premium pay for night work in accordance with subsections (a) and (b) of section 5545
			 and Sunday and holiday pay in accordance with section 5546, without regard
			 to the election of the border patrol agent under subsection (b)(1)(A),
			 except that section 5546(d) shall not apply and eligibility for pay for,
			 and the rate of pay for, any overtime work shall be determined in
			 accordance with this section and section 5542(a)(7); and

shall not be eligible for any other form of premium pay under this title, except as provided in
			 section 5542(a)(7).

Any pay received at the level 1 border patrol rate of pay or the level 2 border patrol rate of pay
			 or pay described in subsection (b)(3)(B) shall be treated as part of basic
			 pay for—
purposes of sections 5595(c), 8114(e), 8331(3), and 8704(c);
any other purpose that the Office of Personnel Management may by regulation prescribe; and
any other purpose expressly provided for by law.

Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the authority of U.S. Customs and Border
			 Protection to require a border patrol agent to perform hours of overtime
			 work in accordance with the needs of U.S. Customs and Border Protection,
			 including if needed in the event of a local or national emergency.

external-xref.#tail: of title 5, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:

term.#tail: has the meaning given that term in section 5550.

text.#text: In this paragraph, the term

Notwithstanding the matter preceding paragraph (1) or paragraphs (1) and (2), for a border patrol
			 agent who has in effect an election to be assigned to the level 1 border
			 patrol rate of pay under section 5550(b)(1)(A)(i)—

except as provided in subparagraph (E), hours of work in excess of 100 hours during a 14-day
			 biweekly pay period shall be overtime work; and
the border patrol agent—

shall receive pay at the overtime hourly rate of pay (as determined in accordance with paragraphs
			 (1) and (2)) for hours of overtime work that are officially ordered or
			 approved in advance of the work assignment; and

shall receive compensatory time off for any hours of overtime work that are not hours of overtime
			 work described in subclause (I).

Notwithstanding the matter preceding paragraph (1) or paragraphs (1) and (2), for a border patrol
			 agent who has in effect an election to be eligible for the level 2 border
			 patrol rate of pay under section 5550(b)(1)(A)(ii)—

except as provided in subparagraph (E), hours of work in excess of 90 hours during a 14-day
			 biweekly pay period shall be overtime work; and
the border patrol agent—

shall receive pay at the overtime hourly rate of pay (as determined in accordance with paragraphs
			 (1) and (2)) for hours of overtime work that are officially ordered or
			 approved in advance of the work assignment; and

shall receive compensatory time off for any hours of overtime work that are not hours of overtime
			 work described in subclause (I).

Notwithstanding the matter preceding paragraph (1) or paragraphs (1) and (2), for a border patrol
			 agent who has in effect an election under section 5550(b)(1)(A)(iii)—

except as provided in subparagraph (E), hours of work in excess of 80 hours during a 14-day
			 biweekly pay period shall be overtime work; and
the border patrol agent—

shall receive pay at the overtime hourly rate of pay (as determined in accordance with paragraphs
			 (1) and (2)) for hours of overtime work that are officially ordered or
			 approved in advance of the work assignment; and

shall receive compensatory time off for any hours of overtime work that are not hours of overtime
			 work described in subclause (I).

Except as provided in clause (ii), during a 14-day biweekly pay period, a border patrol agent shall
			 not perform and may not receive compensatory time off for more than 8
			 hours of overtime work.

U.S. Customs and Border Protection may, as it determines appropriate, waive the limitation under
			 clause (i) for hours of overtime work, but such waiver must be approved in
			 advance of any work being performed that would be subject to compensatory
			 time under subsection (B)(ii)(II), (C)(ii)(II), or (D)(ii)(II).
A border patrol agent—
may not earn more than 240 hours of compensatory time off during a year; and

shall use any hours of compensatory time off not later than 1 year after the date on which the
			 compensatory time off is accrued.

text.#text: A border patrol agent—
may not earn more than 240 hours of compensatory time off during a leave year;

shall use any hours of compensatory time off not later than the end of the 26th pay period after
			 the pay period during which the compensatory time off was earned;
